pbaclace wrote:
> I'm not sure if I should ignore this error, but I see 67,000 of them in a recent crawl.  A search for "Unable to promote prerequisite" does not find anything other than source code:
> 
> 2009-09-26 18:57:19.058 SEVERE thread-27 org.archive.crawler.postprocessor.LinksScoper.handlePrerequisite() Unable to promote prerequisite dns:www.mit.edu above http://www.mit.edu:8001/robots.txt
> 
> This error happens *after* some pages for the site have been saved, usually occurs 3 times in different TOE threads, after that I do not see any activity on that host/domain.

Haven't seen that particular SEVERE log event in years -- pre-1.0.

Are all 67K occurrences for the same server (www.mit.edu:8000), or many 
servers?

Have any URIs been added to the crawl in a way other than as starting 
seeds or outlink-discovery?

What do the last 10-20 lines of the crawl.log for URIs on the 
"www.mit.edu:8000" server show -- any atypical negative error codes? If 
the 'http://www.mit.edu:8001/robots.txt' URI appears in the crawl.log, 
seeing its full line (esp. the hopsPath and via) would be helpful.

This symptom seems to suggest that the 
'http://www.mit.edu:8001/robots.txt' URI was already at 
CandidateURI.HIGHEST (0) scheduling-directive, which by design should 
not occur: most URIs are at NORMAL (3); some seeds/embeds/prerequisites 
can be MEDIUM (2); prerequisites of those can be HIGH (1); and 
prerequisites of those can be HIGHEST (0). There really shouldn't be any 
prerequisite-of-prerequisite ('PP') synthetic hops-paths -- and even a 
2-long path should be a very rare event.

Using the form- or http-auth login features (which also schedule 
'prerequisite' URIs) might make such hops-paths more likely; are those 
in use on this crawl?

- Gordon @ IA
